journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Dynamic analysis of delaminated composite conical shells under low velocity impact

contrib-group.aff: Mechanical Engineering Department, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India

author-notes.corresp: Sudip Dey, Mechanical Engineering Department, Jadavpur University, Kolkata 700032, India. Email: infosudip@gmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The dynamic response of graphite-epoxy delaminated cross-ply composite shallow conical shells subjected to low velocity normal impact is investigated using the finite element method. An eight-noded isoparametric plate bending element is employed in the formulation incorporating rotary inertia and effects of transverse shear deformation based on Mindlin’s theory. In the time integration, Newmark constant average acceleration method in conjunction with an efficient iteration scheme is used. The modified Hertzian contact law which accounts for permanent indentation is utilized to compute the time-dependent equations. Numerical results present the histories of contact force, deflection/thickness and impactor’s displacement for centrally impacted delaminated cross-ply composite cantilevered conical shells.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The investigation on the impact behaviour of delaminated composite materials is motivated by practical situations encountered in the aerospace industry and other fields in which these materials are used extensively. The collision of a foreign object like a bird or a hail-stone on the body of an aircraft is very common during landing and take-off, as well as level flight. The situation is critical when it induces significant internal damage, undetectable by visual inspection which causes the reduction of strength and stability of the structure. Composite structures also pose special problems due to low transverse shear modulus of polymer composites and low interlaminar shear properties. Also, the state of stress within the body of the structures in the vicinity of the impact is very complex. The composite laminates are normally being analyzed by means of classical and first-order shear deformation bending theories. Another problem of concern is the delamination or interlaminar debonding that is often encountered in composite laminates. An accurate assessment of transverse shear stress should be encountered to ensure the structural integrity against interlaminar debonding and other associated failure modes. This, therefore, necessitates the development and use of finite element methods to analyze the transient dynamic response of composite laminates. In general, small amounts of damage are introduced with low-velocity impacts in a small zone surrounding the impact point, and the dynamic properties of the structures usually are not affected by the presence of damage. Therefore, impact dynamic analyses generally do not attempt to model damage as it develops during the impact event. The transverse modulus has a major effect on the contact stiffness. Lowering the contact stiffness also lowers the contact forces and increases the contact area.

The impact response of initially stressed composite plates received attention in the investigations by Sun and Chattopadhyay1 and Sun and Chen.2 The failure analysis of composite plate due to bending and impact was numerically investigated by Parhi et al.3 using finite element method. Karmakar and Kishimoto4 undertook a transient dynamic finite element analysis to investigate the response characteristics of centrally impacted delaminated composite pretwisted rotating cylindrical shells due to low velocity impact. Yiming et al.5 studied the dynamic response of elasto-plastic laminated composite shallow spherical shell under low velocity impact. Khalili et al.6,7 studied transient dynamic response of initially stressed composite cylindrical shell and developed the finite element modeling of low-velocity impact on laminated composite plates and cylindrical shells while transient wave propagation and early short-time transient responses of laminated composite cylindrical shells was investigated by Liu et al.8 Zheng et al.9 investigated on dynamic response characteristics of double-layer composite cylindrical shell subjected to multi-field coupling loadings. The finite element analysis of composite laminates subjected to low-velocity impact damage was recently investigated by Raimondo et al.10 and Shi et al.11 The modeling and characterization of outer shell of motorcyclist helmet made of composite was portrayed by Tinard et al.12 while Setoodeh et al.13 and Zhang et al.14 studied on the transient dynamic and free vibration analysis of functionally graded truncated conical shells. On the other hand, the influence of blast pressure modeling on the dynamic response of conical and hemispherical shells was studied by Kowal-Michalska et al.15 and the continuum damage mechanics approach to composite laminated shallow cylindrical/conical panels under static loading was investigated by Gupta et al.16

Turbomachinery blades could be idealized as pretwisted cantilevered composite conical shells with low aspect ratio. To derive the dynamic equilibrium equation, Lagrange’s equation of motion is used for moderate rotational speeds neglecting the Coriolis effect. An eight-noded isoparametric plate bending element is employed in the finite element formulation. Effects of transverse shear deformation based on Mindlin’s theory and rotary inertia are included. To satisfy the compatibility of deformation and equilibrium of resultant forces and moments at the delamination crack front, a multipoint constraint algorithm is incorporated which leads to unsymmetric stiffness matrices. The modiﬁed Hertzian contact law2 which accounts for permanent indentation is utilized to compute the contact force, and the time-dependent equations are solved by Newmark’s time integration algorithm (constant-average-acceleration method). Parametric studies are performed in respect of location of delamination, angle of twist and velocity of impactor for graphite-epoxy composite conical shells subjected to low-velocity normal impact at the centre.

sec.title: Governing equations
sec.p:
The shallow conical shell with length L, reference width bo, thickness h, vertex angle θv and base subtended angle of cone θo are depicted in Figure 1,17 assuming the cross-section as elliptical. The component of radius of curvature in the chordwise direction Ry(x,y) is a parameter varying both in the x- and y-directions. The variation in x-direction is linear. There is no curvature along the spanwise direction (Rx = ∞). The cantilever shell, clamped along x = 0, is pretwisted with radius of twist Rxy as shown in Figure 1. Thus, a pretwisted shallow conical shell of uniform thickness made of laminated composite is considered. A shallow shell is characterized by its middle surface and is defined by the equation,18 (1)z=-12[x2Rx+2xyRxy+y2Ry] Figure 1.
Geometry of cantilever (a) untwisted conical shell and (b) twisted plate.
The radius of twist (Rxy), length (L) of shell and twist angle (ψ) are related as, (2)tanψ=-LRxy
The non-dimensional coordinate system is given as,17 (3)ξ=xLandη=ybo

The varying radius of curvature is expressed in terms of coordinate system (4)Ry(ξ,η)=βof(ξ,η) where βo is the reference major radius as shown in Figure 1. The function f(ξ,η) can be expressed from the geometry of conical shell and is given by (5)f(ξ,η)=tan(θv/2)sRy(ξ,η) (6)Ry(ξ,η)s=(αs)2(βs)2 {(sβ)2+η2(bos)2(sα)2[(sα)2-(sβ)2]}3/2 where (7)αs=(b/s)(β/s)tan(θo/2)4(β/s)2tan2(θo/2)-(b/s)2 (8)βs=tan(θv/2)[1-(L/s)ξ] (9)bos=2Sin(θv/2)tan2(θo/2)Cos(θv/2)+tan2(θo/2) (10)bs=bos[1-(L/s)ξ]

For the impact problem, {F} is given as (13){F}={0 0 0…FC…0 0 0}T where FC is contact force and equation of motion of rigid impactor is obtained as2 (14)miw··i+FC=0 where mi and w··i are mass and acceleration of impactor, respectively.

sec.title: Contact force
sec.p: The contact force depends on a contact law which relates the contact force with the indentation. The present study concentrate upon composite shallow conical shells having a large ratio of the radius of curvature to its thickness as well as a high value of width-to-thickness ratio. Yang and Sun21 proposed a power law based on static indentation tests using steel balls as indentors. This contact law accounted for permanent indentation after unloading cycles i.e. collisions upon the rebound of the target structure after the first period of contact were considered. The modified version of the above contact law obtained by Tan and Sun22 was used in the analyses of Sun and Chen.2 The centrifugal forces arising out of rotation generate initial stresses and therefore the contact force model following Sun and Chen2 has been incorporated into the present finite element formulation as the study focuses numerical simulation of delaminated graphite-epoxy composite conical shells. If k is the contact stiffness and αm is the maximum local indentation, the contact force FC during loading is evaluated as2 (15)FC=kα1.5,0≤<α≤αm where α is the local indentation i.e., change in distance between centre of the impactor and the mid-surface of target shell and the modified contact stiffness of the Hertzian contact theory proposed by Yang and Sun21 as (16)k=43Ri1[(1-υi2)/Ei+1/Eyy] where Ri, υi and Ei are the radius, Poisson’s ratio and Young’s modulus of elasticity of the impactor, respectively, and Eyy is the modulus of elasticity of the uppermost composite ply in the direction transverse to the fibres. The indentation parameter α depends on the difference of the displacements of the impactor and the target structure at any instant of time, and so also the contact force. The values of α are changing with time because of time-varying displacements of both the rigid impactor and the target structure. So at an instant the maximum indentation takes place and as a result the maximum contact force is also obtained. At this instant, the displacement of the impactor also attains the maximum value. Thereafter, the displacement of the impactor gradually decreases, but the target point displacement keeps on changing and finally increases to a maximum value and at some point of time these two displacements become equal. This leads to zero value of indentation and eventually the contact force becomes zero. At this instant, the impactor looses contact with the target. The process after attaining the maximum contact force till the reduction of contact force to zero value is essentially referred to as unloading. If the mass of the impactor is not very small, a second impact may occur upon the rebound of the target structure leading to a same phenomenon of contact deformation and attainment of maximum contact force. There is always a time gap between the end of the ﬁrst contact period and the beginning of the second impact. This process is known as reloading. If Fm is the maximum contact force at the beginning of unloading and αm is the maximum indentation during loading, the contact force (FC) for unloading and reloading are simulated as2 (17)Fc=Fm[α-αoαm-αo]5/2andFc=Fm[α-αoαm-αo]3/2 where αo denotes permanent indentation in a loading-unloading cycle expressed as2 (18)αo=0whenαm<αcrandαo=βc(αm-αcr)whenαm≥α where βc is a constant and αcr is the critical indentation beyond which permanent indentation occurs, and the respective values are 0.094 and 1.667 × 10−2 cm for graphite-epoxy composite.2 Neglecting the contribution of deflection/thicknesss along global x and y directions, the indentation α is given as23 (19)α(t)=wi(t)-wp(xc,yc,t)Cosψ where wi and wp are displacement of impactor and target deflection/thickness along global z direction at the impact point (xc, yc), respectively, and ψ is the angle of twist. The components of force at the impact point in global directions are given by24 (20)Fix=0,Fiy=FCSinψandFiz=FCCosψ

sec.title: Multipoint constraints
sec.p:
Figure 2 represents the cross-sectional view of a typical delamination crack tip where nodes of three plate elements meet together to form a common node. The undelaminated region is modelled by plate element 1 of thickness h, and the delaminated region is modelled by plate elements 2 and 3 whose interface contains the delamination (h2 and h3 are the thicknesses of the elements 2 and 3, respectively). The elements 1, 2 and 3 are freely allowed to deform prior to imposition of the constraints conditions. The nodal displacements of elements 2 and 3 at crack tip expressed as25 (21)uj=u″j-(z-zj')θxj,vj=v″j-(z-z″j)θyj,wj=w″j (where, j=2,3) where z′j is the z-coordinate of mid-plane of element j and the above equation also holds good for element 1 and z′1 equal to zero. The transverse displacements and rotations at a common node have values expressed as, (22)w1=w2=w3=w,θx1=θx2=θx3=θx,θy1=θy2=θy3=θy Figure 2.
Plate elements at a delamination crack tip.25

In-plane displacements of all three elements at crack tip are equal and they are related as (23)u″2=u1'-z2'θx,v2'=v1'-z2'θy,u3'=u1'-z3'θx,v3'=v1'-z3'θy where u′1 is the mid-plane displacement of element 1. Equations of (22) and (23) relating the nodal displacements and rotations of elements 1, 2 and 3 at the delamination crack tip are the multipoint constraint equations used in finite element formulation to satisfy the compatibility of displacements and rotations. Mid-plane strains between elements 2 and 3 are related as, (24){ɛ'}j={ɛ'}1+zj'{k1} where {ε′} represents the strain vector and {k1} is the curvature vector being identical at the crack tip for elements 1, 2 and 3. This equation can be considered as a special case for element 1 and z′1 is equal to zero. In-plane stress-resultants, {N}, and moment resultants, {M}, of elements 2 and 3 can be expressed as, (25){N}j=[A]j{ɛ'}1+(zj'[A]j+[B]j){k1}(where j=2,3) (26){M}j=[B]j{ɛ'}1+(zj'[B]j+[D]j){k1}(where j=2,3) where [A], [B] and [D] are the extension, bending-extension coupling and bending stiffness coefficients of the composite laminate, respectively. An eight noded isoparametric quadratic plate bending element with five degrees of freedom at each node (three translation and two rotations) is employed wherein the shape functions are given as,14 (27)Ni=(1+ξξi)(1+ηηi)(ξξi+ηηi-1)/4 (for i=1,2,3,4) (28)Ni=(1-ξ2)(1+ηηi)/2 (for i=5,7) (29)Ni=(1-η2)(1+ξξi)/2 (for i=6,8) where ξ and η are the local natural coordinates of the element.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
The results obtained from the computer code developed on the basis of present ﬁnite element modeling are validated with those in the literature both in respect of impact and delamination model. Figure 3(a) and (b) show time histories of contact force and target plate deflection/thickness, respectively, for 10 layered symmetrically laminated cross-ply ([0°/90°/0°/90°/0°]S) composite plate under simply supported boundary condition as analyzed by Sun and Chen2 using finite element technique, while Figure 4 presents variation of fundamental natural frequencies of composite cantilever beam with relative position of the delamination as computed by Krawczuk et al.26 The discrepancies in the results with those of Sun and Chen2 could be attributed to the fact that the present analyses consider the full laminated plate whereas Sun and Chen used quarter plate. Moreover, the number of nodes used in the finite elements, the order of numerical integration and the converged values of time step are different in two cases. The length (L), width (b), radius of curvature (R) and thickness (h) of the shells are adopted as 0.4 m, 0.06732 m, 0.2 m and 0.001 m, respectively. Considering the complete planform of the conical shell a uniform mesh division of 8 × 8 has been used for the analyses. For all the cases, conical shells are centrally impacted by a spherical steel ball of 0.0127 m diameter. The values of the contact stiffness coefficient (k) and mass density of the impactor used in this study are 0.805 × 109 N/m1.5 and 7960 kg/m3, respectively. The material properties2 for computation are adopted as: E1 = 120 GPa, E2 = 7.9 GPa, Ei = 210 GPa, G12 = G23 = G13 = 5.5 GPa, ρ = 1580 kg/m3, νi = ν12 = 0.30. Due to paucity of space, only a few important representative validated results are furnished. Figure 3.
(a) Contact force (b) deflection/thickness with respect to time for centrally impacted cross-ply ([0/90/0/90/0]S) composite plate under simply supported boundary condition, considering laminate dimension 20 cm × 20 cm × 0.269 cm, mass density of impactor = 7.96 × 10–5 N-sec2/cm4, time step = 1.0 µ-sec, E1 = 120 GPa, E2 = 7.9 GPa, Ei = 210 GPa, G12 = G23 = G13 = 5.5 GPa, ρ = 1580 kg/m3, νi = ν12 = 0.3, velocity of impactor = 3 m/s.2
Figure 4.
Influence of relative position of the delamination on fundamental natural frequency of the composite cantilever beam along with symmetry boundary conditions.26

To validate the present finite element formulation in respect of impact response, computation has been carried out for flat isotropic and laminated composite plates. In this context, essentially two important aspects namely analytical solution and finite element treatment have been taken into account. The analysis due to Goldsmith27 for a simply supported 20 cm square and 0.8 cm deep steel plate impacted centrally by a steel sphere of 1 cm radius with initial velocity of 100 cm/sec provides solution of an integral equation for a Hartzian type of contact law in which the contact force is expressed as Fc=κ2α3/2 where κ2=43πR(1δ1+δ2), δ1=(1-υ12)E1π, δ2=(1-υ22)E2π and R is the impactor’s radius and K2 is the contact stiffness. Material parameters considered as E1 = E2 = Ei = 200 GPa, G12 = G23 = G13 = 77 GPa, ρ = 7800 kg/m3, νi = ν12 = 0.3 and the time step chosen is 1.0 µ-sec with corresponding finite element mesh of 8 × 8 for full plate. Figure 5 depicts the comparisons of contact force, central deflection of impactor’s displacement and target deflection/thickness variation with respect to time results obtained from present FEM and that of Goldsmith. The slight discrepancy in the present results can be attributed to the fact that the effect of rotary inertia and transverse shear deformation were neglected by Goldsmith, but the nature of variation is the same. The present analysis compares well with the existing analytical solution. Due to paucity of space, only a few important representative results are furnished. Figure 5.
(a) Contact force and plate displacement (b) impactor’s displacement and velocity with respect to time for simply supported plate impacted at the centre considering flat isotropic laminate dimension a = b = 20 cm, h = 0.8 cm, time step = 1.0 µ-sec, E1 = E2 = Ei = 200 GPa, G12 = G23 = G13 = 77 GPa, ρ = 7800 kg/m3, νi = ν12 = 0.30, initial velocity of impactor = 1 m/s, radius of impact = 0.01 m.27

sec.title: Transient response
sec.p:
Parametric studies are conducted for eight-layered delaminated graphite-epoxy composite cross-ply pretwisted cantilevered conical shells subjected to low velocity normal impact at the centre with respect to location of delamination, velocity of the impactor (VOI) and angle of twist. The arrangement of layers is furnished in Figure 6. Transient response is obtained for untwisted (ψ = 0°) and twisted (ψ = 30°) cantilevered composite conical shells, using the converged value of time step of 1.0 µs for the subject configurations. In each case, 25% delamination is considered irrespective of the location of delamination. At the impact point (L/2, b/2), contact parameters are obtained and the optimum value of time step is chosen after performing convergence study. It is observed that the contact force history increases with the rise of twist angles for cross-ply composite shallow conical shells. In other words, as the twist angle increases, it is found to intensify the contact force and reduce the contact duration of the loading-unloading cycle (first impact). The time interval between completion of unloading and commencement of reloading is widened for cantilevered conical shells wherein the second impact does not occur within the time span of the analyses (e.g. 400 µ-sec). The initial stress is found to increase the softening effect on the laminate stiffness and this may surmise that subsequent dynamic response of the conical shells could be more dangerous even though the maximum contact force is smaller for delaminated cross-ply composite conical shell configuration. This conjecture is confirmed by the deflection/thickness with respect to time diagram wherein the stiffening effect of the tensile prestress is also clearly exhibited. The variation of contact force for different number of delaminations are furnished in Figure 7(a) to (d) while the detail time histories of contact force, deflection/thickness (non-dimensional) and impactor’s displacement are furnished in Figure 8. Figure 6.
Arrangement of layers indicating location of delamination (nd = number of delamination).
Figure 7.
(a, b) Contact force with respect to time for different twist angles ψ = 0°, 30° for different undelaminated (nd = 0) and delaminated (nd = 1) of graphite-epoxy cross-ply composite cantilever conical shells, considering time step = 1.0 µ-sec, E1 = 120 GPa, E2 = 7.9 GPa, Ei = 210 GPa, G12 = G23 = G13 = 5.5 GPa, ρ = 1580 kg/m3, νi = ν12 = 0.3, VOI = 3 m/s, h = 0.002 m, s = 0.8, L/s = 0.7, d/L = 0.5, a/L = 0.25, θo = 45°, θv = 20° (c, d) Contact force with respect to time for different twist angles ψ = 0°, 30° for different number of delamination (nd = 1.4) of graphite-epoxy cross-ply composite cantilevered conical shells, considering time step = 1.0 µ-sec, E1 = 120 GPa, E2 = 7.9 GPa, Ei = 210 GPa, G12 = G23 = G13 = 5.5 GPa, ρ = 1580 kg/m3, νi = ν12 = 0.3, VOI = 3 m/s, h = 0.002 m, s = 0.8, L/s = 0.7, d/L = 0.5, a/L = 0.25, θo = 45°, θv = 20°.
Figure 8.
(a) Contact force (b) deflection/thickness and (c) impactor’s displacement with respect to time for different twist angles ψ = 0°, 30° of multiple delaminated graphite-epoxy cross-ply composite cantilever conical shells, considering time step = 1.0 µ-sec, E1 = 120 GPa, E2 = 7.9 GPa, Ei = 210 GPa, G12 = G23 = G13 = 5.5 GPa, ρ = 1580 kg/m3, νi = ν12 = 0.3, VOI = 3 m/s, number of delamination (nd) = 4, h = 0.002 m, s = 0.8, L/s = 0.7, d/L = 0.5, a/L = 0.25, θo = 45°, θv = 20°.

From Figure 7, the peak value of contact force is found highest for undelaminated case (nd = 0), necked by quadruple delamination (nd = 4) and the lowest value of the same is identified for single mid-plane delaminated case (nd = 1) irrespective of twist angle while the negligible deviation in plate displacement is encountered during loading cycle for all the cases. Hence, it could be inferred that the severe effect due to low velocity normal impact on composite conical shells identified in mid-plane single delaminated case (nd = 1) during the loading cycles. Hence, the structural instability is found to be more predominant at the mid-plane.

sec.title: Effect of location of delamination
sec.p:
The effect of location of delamination on contact force and deflection/thickness and impactor’s displacement with respect to time for single mid-plane delaminated cross-ply composite cantilever conical shells are shown in Figure 9 wherein relative locations of delamination along the span are 0.125, 0.5 and 0.75 are considered from top surface. It can be said that elastic stiffness also changes in the same manner as that of natural frequency with respect to location of delamination along the span of the laminate. In conformity with this, the peak values of the contact force in the later part of the unloading cycle of twisted shells are also found to occur, the peak value of contact force being for relative position at 0.125 and 0.75, while the minimum peak value of contact force identified for relative location at 0.5. It is to be noted that for cantilevered conical shells contact period is completed earlier in case of relative position at 0.75 and 0.125 compared to that of 0.5. In other words, the unloading cycle is found comparatively shorter for relative location at 0.75, followed by relative location at 0.125 and the maximum unloading cycle observed for mid-plane delamination invariant to laminate configurations and twist angles. Like the contact force, deflection/thickness and impactor displacement is also influenced by the relative position of delamination in the later stages of unloading cycle, but no significant variation is noticed during the loading cycle. For a particular location of delamination, the twisted conical shell shows higher peak value of contact force compared to untwisted one irrespective of laminate configurations as expected as the elastic stiffness increases. Natural frequencies of both untwisted and twisted delaminated cantilever conical shells have higher values when the delamination is located near the free surface (top or bottom) compared to its location at the mid-plane and accordingly the elastic stiffness also changes implying lower value corresponding to mid-plane delamination. This is also reﬂected in the plate and impactor’s displacement history during the unloading process. Figure 9.
(a, b) Contact force (c, d) deflection/thickness and (e, f) impactor’s displacement with respect to time (µ-sec) at different relative position of delamination for ψ = 0°, 30° for multiple delaminated graphite-epoxy cross-ply composite cantilever conical shells, considering time step = 1.0 µ-sec, E1 = 120 GPa, E2 = 7.9 GPa, Ei = 210 GPa, G12 = G23 = G13 = 5.5 GPa, ρ = 1580 kg/m3, νi = ν12 = 0.3, VOI = 3 m/s, nd = 4, h = 0.002 m, s = 0.8, L/s = 0.7, d/L = 0.5, a/L = 0.25, θo = 45°, θv = 20°.

sec.title: Effect of velocity of impactor
sec.p:
A centrally point load is considered to be impacted on target by the impactor with velocities of 1 m/sec, 3 m/sec and 5 m/sec, respectively. The present study employed time step of 1.0 µ-sec for obtaining the converged results and the effect of impactor’s velocity is furnished in Figure 10. In general, for a particular laminate configuration and velocity of impactor, contact force of twisted cases is found to be higher than the same of untwisted configurations. It is observed that there exist more fluctuations in contact force for higher velocity of the impactor. It is also found to increase the deflection/thickness with the increase of time. It is also identified that the impactor’s displacement incrementally rises with the increase of velocity of the impactor. These fluctuations could be caused by the participation of more waves of shorter wavelengths or higher modes of vibration induced by higher impact velocities. This corroborates with the findings of Sun and Chen.2 For a particular velocity of the impactor, maximum contact force is identified by twisted cross-ply compared to untwisted cross-ply, while the time required for unloading cycle is observed to be slightly higher for untwisted cross-ply compared to twisted configuration. Hence, it can be inferred that for a particular velocity of impact, maximum contact force has inverse relationship with time required for unloading cycle irrespective of twist angles. Figure 10.
(a, b) Contact force (c, d) deflection/thickness and (e, f) impactor’s displacement with respect to time (µ-sec) at different velocity of impactor (VOI) for ψ = 0°, 30° for multiple delaminated graphite-epoxy cross-ply composite cantilever conical shells, considering time step = 1.0 µ-sec, E1 = 120 GPa, E2 = 7.9 GPa, Ei = 210 GPa, G12 = G23 = G13 = 5.5 GPa, ρ = 1580 kg/m3, νi = ν12 = 0.3, VOI = 3 m/s, n = 8, nd = 4, h = 0.002 m, s = 0.8, L/s = 0.7, d/L = 0.5, a/L = 0.25, θo = 45°, θv = 20°.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The following conclusions are drawn from the present study:
The finite element formulation presented in this paper is validated with the benchmark problems of published literatures and hence this can be successfully applied to analyze the transient dynamic analysis of delaminated composite conical shells subjected to low velocity impact for any laminate configuration.
In general, the maximum value of contact force is found to increase with the rise of twist angles thus maximum contact force of untwisted configuration found is always lower than the maximum contact force of twisted one.
Number of delamination has significant effect on transient dynamic behavior during the unloading cycle for both twisted and untwisted delaminated cross-ply composite cantilever conical shells because of initial stresses.
Relative position of delamination along the span has significant effect for both twisted and untwisted cross-ply composite cantilever conical shells during the unloading cycle only. Contact force is the maximum when the delamination is located near the top or bottom surface of the laminate and the minimum value of contact force are obtained for mid-plane delamination. Hence, the structural instability is found to be more predominant at the mid-plane.
As the velocity of impactor increases, the maximum contact force is also found to increase invariant to twist angle and number of delamination.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
